text: Greece has been very much on the front
line of the refugee and migrant crisis
with hundreds of thousands of people
taking the small dingus and crossing
this sea here to try to make it north
through Europe now the EU says that its
new deal with Turkey is about preventing
people taking that dangerous journey
it's about reducing risk they say and
providing safe alternatives now anyone
who arrives here in Greece faces being
detained and possibly deported
the preparation was last-minute but in
the end the first returns ran smoothly
the non Syrians bust to deportation
centers to be returned to their
countries of origin Syrians taken to
refugee camps to be exchanged with those
directly resettled in the EU but this
was just a symbolic start to meet the
deadline
the next arrivals have been delays
it's still very early days and people
still are getting through but certainly
the numbers look like they're dropping
here on day 2 for example of the New
Deal on lesbos no new arrivals made it
to shore now there are those still 3,000
or so people in the detention camp here
on lesbos and we understand that almost
all of them now have applied for asylum
that process is going to take at least
two weeks European Asylum officers who
are meant to process those claims have
only just arrived here and then the
deportations we think will begin again
and it could be far more challenging as
people who don't want to go back to
Turkey begin to be sent back there
Turkey is the key to solving the migrant
crisis and it's been given incentives
for this deal another three billion
euros the possible lifting of visas for
Turks to travel to most of the EU by the
end of June and the speeding up of its
EU accession process but there is unease
about giving Turkey too much when there
are real concerns about the state of
democracy here
